title: 112_s922
content: The Urban Jobs Act of 2011 may be cited as the ``Urban Jobs Act of 2011''. Congress finds that one-third of minority youth are unemployed, the labor force participation rate is lower for individuals without a high school diploma, African-American and Hispanic students have a lower graduation rate, high school dropouts cost the nation billions in lost wages, and only 52 percent of students in large cities graduate from high school. Only 52 percent of students in large cities graduate from high school, below the national average of 70 percent. High school dropouts earn significantly less over their lifetime, with a $260,000 difference compared to graduates. Additionally, a high percentage of prison inmates have not completed high school, with potential savings of $1.4 billion annually by increasing the high school completion rate. Increasing the high school completion rate by 1 percent for men ages 20 to 60 would save the US $1.4 billion annually in reduced crime costs. A 10% increase in male high school graduation rate could lead to significant reductions in arrest rates for various crimes. The purpose of this Act is to provide resources to prevent disproportionate youth incarceration and prepare them for employment or education leading to economic self-sufficiency. The purpose of this Act is to provide resources to prevent disproportionate youth incarceration and prepare eligible minority youth for employment or education leading to economic self-sufficiency through job training, education, and support services. SEC. 3. URBAN JOBS PROGRAMS. Amends the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 to include a new section on Urban Jobs Programs. The purpose of this section is to provide competitive grants for establishing a feeder system for youth in urban communities, preparing them for employment or education leading to employment, and preventing disproportionate incarceration. The section aims to support youth in urban communities by offering services for entry into employment or education leading to employment and to prevent disproportionate incarceration, especially of minority youth. Definitions include terms like community-based affiliate, eligible youth, and national intermediary. The curr_chunk defines terms like "national intermediary" as a national nonprofit organization with expertise in youth outreach and workforce activities, and "recidivism" as a tendency to return to criminal behavior. The curr_chunk defines terms like "recidivism" as a tendency to return to criminal behavior and "Urban Jobs Program" as a program funded under subsection (c) for workforce activities for youth in 25 States for over 20 years. The Secretary can make grants to national intermediaries for Urban Jobs Programs in urban communities to help eligible youth with employment or education leading to employment. To be eligible for a grant, intermediaries must submit an application with specified information as required by the Secretary. The Secretary requires that grant applications from national intermediaries for Urban Jobs Programs include a request for grant amount, proposed uses of funds, and goals for participants such as increased long-term employment, reduced recidivism, and high school diploma attainment. The grant applications for Urban Jobs Programs must include goals such as reduced recidivism, high school diploma attainment, improved literacy and numeracy, and attainment of industry-recognized certificates or credentials. The program should also have underlying supports like engaged community partners and staff expertise in youth. The grant applications for Urban Jobs Programs must include goals such as reduced recidivism, high school diploma attainment, improved literacy and numeracy, and attainment of industry-recognized certificates or credentials. The program should have underlying supports like engaged community partners, staff expertise in youth development, and demonstrated understanding of youth characteristics. The program will enable participants to achieve outcomes through creating caring relationships with peers and staff, and setting goals for attainment. The Urban Jobs Programs grant applications must include goals such as reduced recidivism, high school diploma attainment, improved literacy, industry-recognized certificates, and community service participation. The Urban Jobs Programs grant applications must include goals such as community service participation, development of workplace skills, sense of responsibility, goal-setting strategies, risk reduction, and improved educational outcomes. The Urban Jobs Program grant applications must include goals such as reduction of risk-taking behaviors, achievement of improved educational outcomes, achievement of improved employment outcomes, reduction of recidivism, and activities leading to industry-recognized certificates or credentials. Eligible activities are also outlined for national intermediaries. The Urban Jobs Program grant applications must include goals such as reduction of risk-taking behaviors, improved educational and employment outcomes, and reduction of recidivism. National intermediaries receiving grants must provide a comprehensive set of services, including case management and educational services leading to industry-recognized certificates or credentials. The curr_chunk focuses on a variety of services including educational enrichment, career pathways, employment activities, support services, health, and nutrition. The curr_chunk discusses various support services such as mentoring, internships, job training, personal development, and housing assistance. It also mentions limitations on fund usage and reporting requirements. The Secretary of Labor must submit reports detailing the progress of Urban Jobs Programs to specific committees. The program is exempt from evaluations required under section 172. Additionally, a National Jobs Council Advisory Committee will be established. The Secretary of Labor will establish the National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, comprised of 11 members from the private sector and high-growth industries, exempt from evaluations under section 172. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee will consist of 11 members from the private sector and high-growth industries, with experience in oversight, hiring, employee training, and employee relations. Members will be appointed for the life of the Committee, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Committee's duties include analyzing and preparing recommendations for the Secretary on the design and operation of certain aspects. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee will analyze and prepare recommendations for the Secretary on the design, operation, and long-term strategic priorities of the program. They will also formulate guidelines for program activities and submit periodic reports to the Secretary. Members of the Committee will not receive compensation for travel expenses. The Committee will submit periodic reports with recommendations to the Secretary. Members will not receive compensation but can claim travel expenses at authorized rates. The Secretary may accept voluntary services from Committee members. The Secretary may accept voluntary and uncompensated services from Committee members. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement. The Committee is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Congress recommends that community-based affiliates establish local jobs council advisory committees. The Congress recommends that community-based affiliates establish local jobs council advisory committees to aid in program implementation and support from the local community.
